This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.', '', '', '', '', '', 'By DAVID FERRIS ', '05/30/2025 06:04 PM EDT', 'President Donald Trump participates in a press conference with Elon Musk in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, May 30, 2025. | Francis Chung/POLITICO', 'It is hard to tell how Elon Musk’s whirlwind four months in Washington were anything but bad news for his biggest company, Tesla.', 'The brand’s sales are falling everywhere, and Americans have increasingly dark views of the electric-car company and its new robotaxi. Musk’s job is to clean up the mess, even though some inside Tesla think he is part of the problem.', 'Today, President Donald Trump officially saw Musk off with a press conference in the Oval Office. “I want to thank Elon for helping,” Trump said, while Musk made clear he’s not done with Washington — a city where he has left plenty of appointees burrowed into the federal bureaucracy, and where his companies have a lot of regulatory and contracting business to conduct. “I’ll continue to be visiting here,” he said.', 'Musk’s track record as a government cost-cutter is up for debate. His bold pledges of cutting $2 trillion from the federal budget when he started the Department of Government Efficiency have shrunk to about $150 billion, and even that is contested. And he has said he worries that the House version of the GOP megabill will erase any gains that DOGE made.', 'And now the Tesla CEO returns to an automaker in a sales and reputational crisis.', 'Sales are down in China, whose home-grown automakers spin out EVs that are cheaper and, to some, more exciting than Tesla’s. Sales are cratering in Europe, where car buyers are enticed by a growing roster of EVs — including China’s — and turned off by Musk’s embrace of far-right figures.', 'And in Tesla’s home U.S. market, there’s abundant evidence that Musk has vaporized the company’s goodwill. It turns out that being the strident face of mass government layoffs isn’t a great look when many of your company’s customers were drawn to the Musk who made gasoline-free transportation cool.', 'Reviving Tesla
A survey in early May asked more than 8,000 Americans what they thought of EV automakers. The poll by the Electric Vehicle Intelligence Report found that Tesla’s reputation was the worst across every demographic, and 38 percent said their views had darkened over the past six months.', 'Musk intends to work his way out of this bind by focusing on Tesla’s new and disruptive projects: the Optimus robot and the robotaxi, which Musk just confirmed will take to the streets of Austin in June. There too, Tesla faces headwinds.', 'Meanwhile, moves that Congress made last week could collectively slash Tesla’s profits and make it harder for Detroit automakers and smaller EV competitors like Rivian to succeed. The House’s version of the Republican megabill would eliminate incentives to buy and make EVs, while the Senate voted to kill California’s Environmental Protection Agency waiver that allowed the state to require high EV sales.', 'The end of that waiver — combined with Trump’s watering down of emissions standards — will eliminate credits that Tesla could have earned by selling them to other automakers. Federal and state regulatory credits have earned Tesla $10.7 billion over a decade.', 'So the return of Musk to Tesla is something of a mixed blessing. On the plus side: Dan Ives, a financial analyst for Wedbush Securities, called Musk’s new focus “music to the ears of Tesla shareholders.”', 'Now Tesla’s chief has to show he can change the narrative.', 'It’s Friday — thank you for tuning in to POLITICO’s Power Switch. The Environmental Protection Agency’s upcoming proposal to undo Biden-era limits on power plants’ greenhouse gas emissions is expected to argue that the U.S. electricity sector doesn’t contribute “significantly” to climate change.', 'If EPA’s argument survives legal challenges, it could offer cover for the agency to stop regulating planet-warming emissions from a wide range of sources under the Clean Air Act, Jean Chemnick reports.', 'Cycle of litigation
Trump’s energy emergency declaration has offered help to oil, gas and coal companies trying to get federal permits faster and, therefore, build faster. But Trump’s moves could backfire, leaving projects tied up in court for years, Mike Soraghan reports.', 'The reality is that Congress hasn’t repealed the environmental laws that guide permitting and environmental analysis. And though a Thursday ruling by the Supreme Court limited the scope of environmental reviews, agencies will still be required to thoroughly examine the direct effects of energy projects.', 'Europe’s 2040 goal
The European Commission’s 2040 climate target is expected on July 2. EU Climate Commissioner Wopke Hoekstra said this week that the EU executive would propose a 90 percent target for cutting emissions.', 'The plan builds in flexibility for individual countries. For instance, countries could meet their goals through the use of international carbon credits tied to overseas projects, Zia Weise reports.', 'Cut through policy complexity and turn intelligence into action with POLITICO’s Policy Intelligence Assistant—a new suite of tools designed to save you time and demonstrate your impact more easily than ever—available only to Pro subscribers. Save hours, uncover critical insights instantly, and stay ahead of the next big shift. Power your strategy today—learn more.', 'Costs piling up: Many of Trump’s regulatory reversals will pile more costs onto individual Americans in the form of higher bank fees and electricity and water bills.', 'Cutting rigs: U.S. drillers cut the number of oil and natural gas rigs operating for a fifth week in a row to the lowest since November 2021, according to Baker Hughes.', 'A showcase of some of our best subscriber content.', 'Katy Frank (left), a former computer scientist at the NOAA Great Lakes Environmental Research Lab, protests in Detroit earlier this year after losing her job. | Paul Sancya/AP', 'Staff shortages and red tape are suffocating the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and threatening its ability to accurately predict extreme weather events.', 'Oregon-based NuScale Power on Thursday won approval from U.S. nuclear regulators for its second small modular reactor design.', 'The Department of Energy canceled $3.7 billion in grants Friday for cutting emissions at fossil fuel and industrial projects, a sign that more award cancellations are possible.', 'The Interior Department said Friday that it is adopting “emergency” procedures to help speed the review and permitting of geothermal projects, including three planned projects in Nevada.', 'That’s it for today, folks. Tesla Shareholders Very Glad to Have Musk Back
‘Next Destination: $2 Trillion,’ Says Daniel Ives About Tesla Stock
Paragraphs:
['The one thing Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) investors hoped for has finally happened. Nope, we’re not talking about a Cybertruck actually being sold – rather, that CEO Elon Musk has decided he’s attended enough dinner parties at Mar-a-Lago and it’s time to head back to more familiar pastures.', '', '', 'After his brand-destroying exploits as the chainsaw-wielding arm of the Trump administration, Musk has brought his political activities to a close (for now). Musk officially stepped down from his position in the Trump administration last Wednesday night, bringing to an end a controversial and widely criticized tenure as a senior adviser to the president and the unofficial leader of DOGE (Department of Government Efficiency).', 'That, says Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives, is “music to the ears of Tesla shareholders.”', '“While Trump mentioned that Musk will stay on as an advisor, we believe that Musk’s days in politics are essentially over after this experiment that clearly morphed into brand damage for Tesla and took on a life of its own,” the 5-star analyst said. “With the rollout of robotaxi launch coming up on June 12th following the recent announcement that TSLA has been testing driverless Model Ys for several days already, it was the best possible news Tesla investors could have heard with TSLA’s most important asset now fully focused on the autonomous/robotics path.”', 'Musk’s involvement with the White House was responsible for a “20% overhang on the stock,” yet that has now been lifted. Ives thinks this “dark chapter” can now be put to rest, and from hereon in, Musk is all set to lead “this autonomous and robotics future.”', 'In fact, Ives believes Tesla is still “the most undervalued AI play” out there. It’s true, he says, Tesla’s autonomous and robotics strategic vision, just like Rome, will not be built in a day. Setbacks are inevitable, but Tesla’s unparalleled global scale and reach position it to lead the autonomous vehicle market – and potentially license its technology to other automakers both in the U.S. and internationally in the future. And that should set Tesla stock on a path to reach a $2 trillion valuation over the next 12 to 18 months.', '“We see the true autonomous winner as Tesla and over the coming year more investors will recognize this AI vision with Musk back in the driver’s seat,” Ives summed up optimistically.', 'All told, Ives assigns an Outperform (i.e., Buy) rating to TSLA shares, along with a Street-high $500 price target. The implication for investors? A potential upside of 44% from current levels. (To watch Ives’ track record, click here)', 'That exuberant take contrasts with most current TSLA theses. The stock only claims a Hold (i.e., Neutral) consensus rating, based on a mix of 16 Buys, 10 Holds and 11 Sells. Title: Dan Ives: This is going to be a golden era for Tesla
Paragraphs: ['Tesla is not just a car company; it is a technological juggernaut poised to redefine the future of transportation, automation, and human-robot interaction. With innovations spanning self-driving vehicles, robotaxis, and humanoid robots, Tesla is on the cusp of what Wedbush analyst Dan Ives calls a transformative period. “This is really going to be a golden era for Tesla,” Ives declared in a recent interview with CNBC, encapsulating the boundless optimism surrounding the company’s trajectory. Under the visionary leadership of Elon Musk, Tesla is not merely innovating—it is reshaping the very fabric of how we live and move in the world.', 'At the heart of this revolution is Tesla’s unmatched ability to scale its technologies. Ives emphasized, “Tesla is unmatched when it comes to its ability to scale robotaxis,” highlighting the company’s engineering prowess and execution capabilities as key differentiators. While competitors like Waymo have made strides in limited markets, Tesla’s global vision and infrastructure position it leagues ahead. As Ives noted, “On the world stage, when Tesla gets to scale, everyone else will pay rent.” This isn’t just about market dominance; it’s about setting the standard for autonomous technology worldwide.', 'The Dawn of Autonomous Innovation', 'The upcoming robotaxi launch on June 12th in Austin, Texas, marks a pivotal moment. “June 12th in Austin is just the start of what’s going to be the autonomous vision,” Ives told CNBC, signaling the beginning of a broader rollout. He predicts rapid expansion, stating, “A year from now, Cybercabs are going to be in 10-20 cities.” This ambitious timeline reflects Tesla’s commitment to turning science fiction into reality, with self-driving vehicles poised to transform urban mobility by reducing congestion and enhancing safety.', 'Tesla’s investors have every reason to celebrate. “It’s a pop the champagne moment for Tesla investors,” Ives exclaimed, pointing to Musk’s renewed focus on the company after stepping back from government roles. This refocus is seen as a catalyst for growth, with Ives projecting, “We’re looking at a $2 trillion market cap for Tesla.” Such a valuation underscores the market’s belief in Tesla’s disruptive potential, not just in automotive but across multiple tech sectors.', 'A Broader Technological Ecosystem', 'Beyond robotaxis, Tesla’s ambitions extend to humanoid robots and broader AI applications, positioning it alongside another tech industry giant. “Tesla, along with Nvidia, are going to be the best disruptive technology companies in the world,” Ives asserted on CNBC. Projects like the Optimus robot hint at a future where Tesla’s innovations permeate daily life, from industrial automation to personal assistance. Ives sees Tesla as the linchpin of Musk’s empire, stating, “I think ultimately the golden goose, the hearts and lungs of the Musk ecosystem is Tesla.”', 'The road ahead is not without challenges, but Tesla’s track record suggests it will overcome them and likely exceed expectations. “The biggest chapter of Tesla’s growth story is ahead of us,” Ives concluded, capturing the electric anticipation by many surrounding the company. Tesla isn’t just building cars or robots; it’s crafting a future where technology serves humanity in unprecedented ways. For those following closely, the message is clear: Tesla is just getting started, and the world will never be the same.', 'Subscribe for Updates', '', 'Get the free daily newsletter read by decision makers', '', 'Deliver your marketing message directly to decision makers.']

Title: For Dan Ives, Tesla Outpaces Waymo in the Race for Autonomous Dominance
Paragraphs: ['There are two kinds of individuals in the self-driving race, those who are still gawking at robotaxi demos in trial cities and those who are strapping themselves in for Tesla’s highway domination. As Waymo continues to edge along with caution and city approvals, Elon Musk is looking toward a future where a vehicle doesn’t merely drive itself, it basically operates the software from the dashboard.', 'As the autonomous vehicle competition heats up around the world, investors are always in search of the most exciting companies to invest in. While Alphabet’s self-driving division, Waymo, keeps making news with its robotaxi tests, Wedbush senior analyst Dan Ives considers Tesla the true long-term value player. From scalability to engineering strength, Ives contends that Tesla’s advantage extends far beyond flashy demonstrations and into the arena of sustainable disruption.', 'Waymo has drawn attention to itself for rolling out robotaxis independently in very few selected cities of the U.S. Dan Ives identifies one critical limitation, which is its scalability. He said,', '“Waymo essentially operates in four cities … the question is: can it scale?”', 'Through years of development and research under Alphabet’s broad umbrella, Waymo still has not seen past niche deployments. It has a limited reach, which questions whether the company can transition from pilot to operational at scale. Though their technology is great, the business model and market traction are up in the air.', 'Tesla, on the other hand, is not starting with a clean sheet on its autonomous play. It has a worldwide fleet of millions of vehicles on the road, all providing real-time feedback back into its network. This closed loop enables Tesla to iterate on its Full Self-Driving (FSD) system on an ongoing basis, based on real-world conditions, not test rigs.', 'Dan Ives attributes this system of learning in the real world as a major differentiator. He said,', '“When it comes to scale, I view TSLA as unmatched relative to engineering talent and the ability to scale. I believe we’re sitting here a year from now and Cybercabs are going to be in 10, 15, 20 cities”.', 'Tesla’s vertically integrated manufacturing, in-house chip design, and internal software provide it with a multi-faceted superiority over industry rivals still dependent on external suppliers and bounded tests.', 'Tesla shareholders welcomed Elon Musk’s recent withdrawal from his political advisory position in the Trump campaign as a pivotal moment. The move was declared by Ives as a “pop-the-champagne moment for Tesla investors,” indicating that Musk has his full attention on the company once again.', 'Musk’s return to Tesla’s operations is likely to speed up critical projects, such as the expansion of autonomous driving capabilities and the rollout of “Cybercabs,” a name given to Tesla’s future fleet of robotaxis. As per Ives, in the next year, these self-driving cabs might be in use in “10, 15, 20 cities.”', 'Wedbush is still very bullish about Tesla, giving it an “Outperform” rating with a brave price target of $500. It is much higher than the current consensus of EV stock, which currently sits at “hold” with a price target of  $309. The company views Tesla not just as an automaker, but as a revolutionary AI and robotics giant in the making.', 'Ives said,', '“I think we’re going to look at the next year or two as the golden era for Tesla.”', 'The June 12 Investor Day in Austin is likely to provide more insight into Tesla’s vision for FSD and its humanoid robot aspirations, which are two of the areas most likely to reshape the company’s image and market profile.', 'While Chinese rivals such as BYD keep closing the gap with low-cost vehicles and technology-enabled features, Ives asserts that Tesla’s global size, software capabilities, and brand value provide it with a superior advantage. Tesla’s capacity to innovate at scale and deliver across the globe positions it in a class of its own. Its vehicles aren’t mere cars, they are intelligent, upgradable platforms that become better over time, it is an advantage no incumbent carmaker or new player has so far equaled.', 'For investors willing to put their money on the autonomous revolution, Waymo’s narrow market penetration and absence of commercial scalability restraint its potential. Tesla, on the other hand, is already setting the infrastructure in place for mass-market rollout of self-driving technology, supported by information and manufacturing capabilities. Dan Ives said,', '“Leaders lead, the biggest chapter of Tesla’s growth story is ahead of us. Biggest asset for Tesla is Musk, and this ends what was really a dark chapter for TSLA investors.”', 'In the intensely competitive surge towards autonomy, Waymo may be the refined academic, with glossy theories, pilot projects, and an exemplary safety record, but Tesla is the street smart troublemaker making headlines and devouring market share in real time. Yes, Waymo may pass the test track, but Tesla is already making its way through the gritty corners of reality across the globe. With tens of millions of rolling data centers powering its neural net and Musk once again focusing on his technology, Tesla isn’t simply reaching for the future, it’s building it at scale. As the world of EVs travels toward full self-driving capability, for those who want to get in on the next wave of innovation in mobility, Tesla could be the ticket.', 'Disclosure: Some of the links in this article are affiliate links and we may earn a small commission if you make a purchase, which helps us to keep delivering quality content to you.', 'AUTHOR', 'Fatimah Misbah Hussain is a tech journalist at TECHi.com, specializing in government policy, cybersecurity, and digital user experiences. Title: Has Elon Musk left Tesla in bad odour?
Paragraphs: ['Now showing content from the last twelve months, not just the past six days.', 'T\nhree years before the outbreak of the First World War, the Prince Henry was laying claim to be what we would now call one of the world’s first supercars, a true rival to the original Silver Ghost which made the name of Rolls-Royce.', 'The Prince Henry was manufactured by Vauxhall. The British company was at the forefront of the nascent automotive revolution, so much so that after the Great War it was acquired by General Motors of the US.', 'Fifty years later GM had turned Vauxhall into an everyman marque. Another half century on to the present day and Vauxhall, much diminished, looks more of a historical peculiarity, a brand which claims to be British but whose foreign owner builds no cars here and after the closure of the Luton factory, few vans.', '• Business live: Wise moves primary listing to New York in blow to London', 'But this is not about Vauxhall. It is about how the extraordinary can become ordinary.', 'Tesla’s UK sales fell by 45 per cent in May. The once dominant electric car manufacturer is now running pretty much neck-and-neck with the all-electric models produced by both BMW and Volkswagen. Take in the latter’s stable of brands such as Audi and Skoda, VW is now by some way the pre-eminent seller of electric cars in Britain.', 'In a further indication that the once extraordinary Tesla has become just another ordinary car company, it has abandoned its stance of never explaining its UK performance and is instead now briefing out its excuses.', 'Tesla’s version of events is that it has had trouble in the upgrade to its next-generation bestselling Model Y, that the ramp-up of production at its European plant Giga Berlin has been problematic.', 'Of course the narrative everywhere else is that Tesla’s falling sales is all to do with its chief executive Elon Musk scoring heavily on the pratometer of billionaire businessmen and who has become just another hurdle to the adoption of an electric car.', 'So, have we passed Peak Tesla? Tesla would argue we should not be looking at May’s figures but what is happening this month with larger order fulfilment of the new Model Y. The June sales figures may show Tesla is still very much in the game. If they don’t then we will know just how big a buffoon Musk has been.', 'Having got it so wrong about Discover IE, the market is making up for lost time. Discover IE is one of the hidden gems of the FTSE 250. But a mid-cap, mid-tech company is all some investors seem to see. They ignore the fundamentals: a well-run, acquisitive outfit with experienced executives concentrating on the manufacturing flexibility which creates margin growth even when sales are stodgy, supplying electronic and sensor components in all the right markets such as industrial automation, data centres and security.', 'Where the market got it so completely wrong was seeing Discover IE as hopelessly exposed to the Trump trade wars because 25 per cent of its business is in the US, much of it imported. The company hit a six-year low on Trump’s “liberation day”.', 'Discover IE made it plain: its model means it is flexible enough to switch output to the US; and its Asian rivals would be hurting far more from tariffs than it would. Its results on Wednesday were a vindication of a policy of keep-calm-and-carry-on but didn’t particularly blow the doors off.', 'A 15 per cent spurt in the shares, though, means the stock is now 50 per cent higher than just two months ago. This is an unglamorous industrial company. It is not normal.', 'Maybe chief executives don’t think about these things too much but Phil Bentley will be flashing a grin as his Mitie caretaking company overtakes its old rival Serco to be the first to get back through the £2 billion level after the outsourcing armageddon of the past decade.', 'And he’s keen on getting even bigger. Having engineered a clever acquisition of the best remaining bits of the carnage at Interserve, it has emerged Bentley covets Marlowe, another peer but at the smarter end of the game: office environmental testing and personnel services.', 'A rare plc-on-plc deal, a putative takeover would cost Mitie more than £300 million if the leap in Marlowe’s share price was anywhere near right.', 'Lord Ashcroft, who founded Marlowe, whose offices are festooned with images of the fictional gumshoe Philip with whom it shares a name, would pocket about £60 million.', 'Small change for the billionaire businessman but enough to bankroll a few more of his publications on some of the Chandleresque characters who have been running the Conservative Party.', 'While the fall in Tesla’s sales in the latest monthly car registrations will no doubt be the headline piece of data, the continuing state of electric car sales will be worth mentioning in dispatches.', 'Word is that about 22 per cent of all new cars registered in May were all-electric. Title: Elon Musk Back in @Tesla but Will DOGE Affect Linger?
Paragraphs: ['auto connected car news', 'Elon Musk has officially stepped down from his role as head of the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), a position he held for 130 days under President Donald Trump’s administration. Musk’s tenure was marked by ambitious goals to streamline federal operations and reduce spending. While the administration claims DOGE achieved approximately $170 billion in savings, critics argue that the cuts adversely affected community services and led to legal challenges regarding the authority and impact of the department.', 'Musk’s departure from DOGE has been met with mixed reactions. Supporters praise his efforts to bring private-sector efficiency to government, while detractors highlight the disruption caused by abrupt budget cuts and the lack of substantial reform . In a recent interview, Musk acknowledged the challenges faced during his tenure, describing the federal bureaucracy as “much worse” than anticipated and labeling the experience as an “uphill battle”.', 'Following his exit from public service, Musk has indicated a renewed focus on his private ventures, particularly Tesla. This shift comes at a critical time, as Tesla faces significant sales declines in key markets. In China, Tesla’s second-largest market, sales have dropped amid intensifying competition from domestic  EV manufacturers like BYD and NIO. Similarly, in Canada, Tesla’s sales in Quebec plummeted by over 85% in the first quarter of 2025 compared to the previous quarter, partly due to the suspension of federal EV incentives.', 'Despite these challenges, Tesla’s stock has remained resilient, buoyed by investor optimism surrounding the company’s advancements in autonomous driving technology and the anticipated launch of its robotaxi service. Musk’s return to Tesla’s helm is seen as a strategic move to navigate the company through its current headwinds and capitalize on emerging opportunities in the EV market.', 'As Musk refocuses on Tesla, the broader implications of his brief foray into government service continue to unfold. While his efforts at DOGE sparked debate over the role of private-sector leaders in public administration, the lasting impact of his policies remains a subject of scrutiny and discussion.', 'Looking forward, analysts predict that Musk’s renewed leadership at Tesla will coincide with a broader realignment of the company’s sales strategy. Tesla is reportedly doubling down on affordability and domestic manufacturing, aiming to maintain market share in North America while regaining ground internationally.', 'With new gigafactories coming online and cost-cutting innovations underway—such as structural battery packs and simplified vehicle platforms—the company may be positioned to roll out a new, lower-cost EV aimed at competing with offerings from Chinese rivals.Still, skeptics warn that these changes may take years to bear fruit, leaving Tesla vulnerable in the short term.', 'Meanwhile, Musk’s public image continues to be a double-edged sword.His involvement in politics through DOGE alienated some longtime Tesla supporters who viewed the move as a distraction, while endearing him further to conservative and libertarian factions.', 'As he exits the political stage, questions remain about whether his controversial stances and policy experiments will impact consumer sentiment—and by extension, Tesla’s brand.', 'Add AUTO Connected Car News to your Google News Feed.', 'X "Twitter": @aconnectedcar', 'LinkedIn']

Title: ‘Next Destination: $2 Trillion,’ Says Daniel Ives About Tesla Stock
Paragraphs: ['The one thing Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) investors hoped for has finally happened. Nope, we’re not talking about a Cybertruck actually being sold – rather, that CEO Elon Musk has decided he’s attended enough dinner parties at Mar-a-Lago and it’s time to head back to more familiar pastures.', '', '', 'After his brand-destroying exploits as the chainsaw-wielding arm of the Trump administration, Musk has brought his political activities to a close (for now). Musk officially stepped down from his position in the Trump administration last Wednesday night, bringing to an end a controversial and widely criticized tenure as a senior adviser to the president and the unofficial leader of DOGE (Department of Government Efficiency).', 'That, says Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives, is “music to the ears of Tesla shareholders.”', '“While Trump mentioned that Musk will stay on as an advisor, we believe that Musk’s days in politics are essentially over after this experiment that clearly morphed into brand damage for Tesla and took on a life of its own,” the 5-star analyst said. “With the rollout of robotaxi launch coming up on June 12th following the recent announcement that TSLA has been testing driverless Model Ys for several days already, it was the best possible news Tesla investors could have heard with TSLA’s most important asset now fully focused on the autonomous/robotics path.”', 'Musk’s involvement with the White House was responsible for a “20% overhang on the stock,” yet that has now been lifted. Ives thinks this “dark chapter” can now be put to rest, and from hereon in, Musk is all set to lead “this autonomous and robotics future.”', 'In fact, Ives believes Tesla is still “the most undervalued AI play” out there. It’s true, he says, Tesla’s autonomous and robotics strategic vision, just like Rome, will not be built in a day. Setbacks are inevitable, but Tesla’s unparalleled global scale and reach position it to lead the autonomous vehicle market – and potentially license its technology to other automakers both in the U.S. and internationally in the future. And that should set Tesla stock on a path to reach a $2 trillion valuation over the next 12 to 18 months.', '“We see the true autonomous winner as Tesla and over the coming year more investors will recognize this AI vision with Musk back in the driver’s seat,” Ives summed up optimistically.', 'All told, Ives assigns an Outperform (i.e., Buy) rating to TSLA shares, along with a Street-high $500 price target. The implication for investors? A potential upside of 44% from current levels. (To watch Ives’ track record, click here)', 'That exuberant take contrasts with most current TSLA theses. The stock only claims a Hold (i.e., Neutral) consensus rating, based on a mix of 16 Buys, 10 Holds and 11 Sells. ['So now that Elon Musk is running off into a ketamine-fueled sunset to preside over his failing business empire, leaving government presumably forever, it might be tempting to shift our attention away from him. ', 'Currently, only GM and Toyota have 17% and 15% of the U.S. car market for ICE cars, hybrids, and EVs. So if Tesla has 15% (much less 25%) of the EV market in 5 or 6 years when EVs will make up a much larger share of the total car market than they do now, that would put it far from bankruptcy. But even so, for EV sales in the U.S. in the first quarter of 2025, among the top 10 best-sellers, at 131,000 of three models, Tesla sold more than twice as many of its as all the other models combined,  The next best seller, the Ford Mustang Mach-E and Ford F-150 Lightning for total sales of 18,794. ', 'All of what you wrote is true...and is a reminder that there is still lots of downward potential for Tesla if the car buyers in the U.S. were to start behaving as they are in Europe.  And with the declines in Europe and China, Tesla badly needs the U.S. market, so we do have a lot of power over the company.', 'And it’s not like it is a sacrifice to not buy one of their cars — exterior styling ranges from godawful hideous (Cybertruck) to bland (Model Y) to okay (Model 3), the interiors are spartan and overly dependent on the touch screen, and the company has largely quit innovating and allowed its product line to get stagnant while Musk makes ridiculous promises that the company repeatedly fails to deliver on.', 'I certainly encourage people to buy an EV.  If you want a compact SUV, you can choose a Chevy Equinox EV over the Model Y, saving close to $10k in the process while getting a better looking vehicle.  Or choose a Kia EV6 or Hyundai Ioniq 5 that will charge much faster than that Model Y.  If you’re looking at a sedan (some of us still want a car, not an SUV), The Hyundai Ioniq 6 offers distinctive styling (I have one and love it, but I know that not everyone feels the same way) and the same super-fast charging as the EV6/Ioniq 5 — and I can say from personal experience that it is a super-comfortable car that is responsive and fun to drive.  Mind you, there are also solid options from many other companies (Rivian, Lucid, Ford, VW) that you may want to consider — my list is not inclusive.', 'Nissan’s Araya is also an excellent car. That said, the driver assist/warning features are quite good (although I turn off the lane following feature if the road lines are faded or if there are a lot of exits).', 'Ioniq 6 here and love it', 'I’m definitely glad someone other than Tesla came out with one.  It might be my next car depending on if anyone else makes a sedan by the time I am shopping again.', 'The Kia EV4 is a sedan that is supposedly coming to the U.S. for (I think) the 2026 model year).   Other than that, I’m not aware of any other non-luxury EV sedans that are available or coming soon here (aside from the Ioniq 6 and Model 3).  ', 'Note that the EV4 is likely to be a little smaller and less expensive than the Ioniq 6, but also will not charge as fast since it will only have 400V architecture — but it should still charge about as fast as the Model 3.', "I guess it's technically a sedan, but why did they try so hard to make it look like a hatchback?", 'Since it is not a real common vehicle, it’s always nice to see one or hear from someone else that has one.', 'My favorite place for spotting another Ioniq 6 is now the one that I saw while visiting Germany recently.  My partner and I were staying in the small Bavarian town of Kochel and had walked down to the Kochelsee and were on our way back when an Ioniq 6 went zipping by.  The combination of a great car in one of the most beautiful places. ', 'I recently bought a Ford Mustang Mach E and love it. A couple years ago, I was planning to  buy a Tesla. I put that off when Elon warped twitter.  So I waited until the day before the tariff announcement and bought a different American brand. Better late than never.', 'Also a good choice.', 'I think that there are a lot of us who once saw Tesla as an aspirational vehicle.  What killed it for me was when the Model 3 came out and routed so many basic vehicle controls through that touch screen. ['Elon Musk shared a video this afternoon, in an apparent attempt to salvage Tesla’s reputation and his public relationship with President Trump.', 'The founder of the world’s leading electronic vehicle company has suffered a huge blow to his public image since aligning himself with Trump during the president’s presidential campaign. Some even credited the South African-born genius with helping him secure a second term as president. Trump repaid his loyalty with a special position as head of the Department of Government Efficiency.', 'But during his time in the role, Musk’s controversial opinions and actions sparked outrage and widespread riots targeting Tesla vehicles and dealerships.', 'Today, just a few days after announcing his time in the position had come to an end, Musk shared a video originally posted on March 11, writing, “Remember this? @realDonaldTrump.”', 'The video showed the Tesla billionaire and Trump side by side along with Musk’s son, X. In the video, Trump heaps praise on Musk, saying he “never asked (me) for a thing” adding, “He’s built this great company. He shouldn’t be penalized because he is a patriot.”', 'Trump did not respond to the video, but many X users did, speculating about what Musk’s intentions might have been for sharing the video. Some poked fun at Musk for reflecting on the “good old days like a desperate ex” when he and the president were on better terms.', 'Just two days ago, Musk came out swinging against Trump’s ‘Big Beautiful Bill’ calling the reconciliation package a “disgusting abomination.” It was the first time he had publicly slammed one of Trump’s policies in such a manner, solidifying rumors that there was a rift between the duo.', 'Other users speculated that the bizarre tweet, which comes in the middle of an obvious divide between the two, might be a desperate attempt from Musk to remedy the damage done to Tesla during his time as head of DOGE.', 'Since the feud rumors began, Tesla shares have plunged 17%, according to BNO News. The electric vehicle company has been facing a challenging period, with dwindling sales attributed to the company’s bad reputation.', 'Today, Musk shocked followers when he followed the seemingly sweet video of Trump praising Tesla, with a tweet that read, "Time to drop the really big bomb: @realDonaldTrump is in the Epstein files. Title: How Trump and Musk’s relationship flamed out
Paragraphs:
['Your favorite shows at PBS are in danger of going away. The federal funding that supports local stations and public media is under threat.', '', 'Michelle L. Price, Associated Press', 'Leave your feedback', 'WASHINGTON (AP) — Donald Trump and Elon Musk’s alliance took off like one of SpaceX’s rockets. It was supercharged and soared high. And then it blew up.', 'The spectacular flameout Thursday peaked as Trump threatened to cut Musk’s government contracts and Musk claimed that Trump’s administration hasn’t released all the records related to sex abuser Jeffrey Epstein because Trump is mentioned in them.', 'READ MORE: In escalating public feud, Trump threatens to cut Musk’s government contracts', 'The tech entrepreneur even shared a post on social media calling for Trump’s impeachment and skewered the president’s signature tariffs, predicting a recession this year.', 'The messy blow-up between the president of the United States and the world’s richest man played out on their respective social media platforms after Trump was asked during a White House meeting with Germany’s new leader about Musk’s criticism of his spending bill.', 'Trump had largely remained silent as Musk stewed over the last few days on his social media platform X, condemning the president’s so-called “Big Beautiful Bill.” But Trump clapped back Thursday in the Oval Office, saying he was “very disappointed in Musk.”', 'Musk responded on social media in real time. Trump, who was supposed to be spending Thursday discussing an end to the Russia-Ukraine war with German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, ratcheted up the stakes when he turned to his own social media network, Truth Social, and threatened to use the U.S. government to hurt Musk’s bottom line by going after contracts held by his internet company Starlink and rocket company SpaceX.', '“The easiest way to save money in our Budget, Billions and Billions of Dollars, is to terminate Elon’s Governmental Subsidies and Contracts,” Trump wrote on his social media network.', 'WATCH: Trump says he’s ‘very disappointed’ in Elon Musk after criticism of president’s budget bill', '“Go ahead, make my day,” Musk quickly replied on X.', 'Hours later, Musk announced SpaceX would begin decommissioning the spacecraft it used to carry astronauts and cargo to the International Space Station for NASA.', 'Musk also said, without offering evidence of how he might know the information, that Trump was “in the Epstein files. That is the real reason they have not been made public. Have a nice day, DJT!”', 'The deepening rift unfurled much like their relationship started — rapidly, intensely and very publicly. And it quickly hit Musk financially.', 'READ MORE: Musk says he will cut back on political spending after paying at least $250M backing Trump in 2024', 'After Trump started criticizing Musk, shares of his electric vehicle company Tesla plunged more than 14%, knocking about $150 billion off Tesla’s market valuation. Musk lost about $20 billion on his personal holding of Tesla.', 'Politicians and their donor patrons rarely see eye to eye. But the magnitude of Musk’s support for Trump, spending at least $250 million backing his campaign, and the scope of free rein the president gave him to slash and delve into the government with the Department of Government Efficiency is eclipsed only by the speed of their falling-out.', 'Musk offered up an especially stinging insult to a president sensitive about his standing among voters: “Without me, Trump would have lost the election,” Musk retorted. “Such ingratitude,” Musk added in a follow-up post.', 'Musk first announced his support for Trump shortly after the then-candidate was nearly assassinated on stage at a Pennsylvania rally last July. News of Musk’s political action committee in support of Trump’s election came days later.', 'Musk soon became a close adviser and frequent companion, memorably leaping in the air behind Trump on stage at a rally in October. Once Trump was elected, the tech billionaire stood behind him as he took the oath of office, flew on Air Force One for weekend stays at Mar-a-Lago, slept in the Lincoln Bedroom and joined Cabinet meetings wearing a MAGA hat — sometimes more than one.', 'Three months ago, Trump purchased a red Tesla from Musk as a public show of support for his business as it faced blowback.', 'Musk bid farewell to Trump last week in a somewhat somber news conference in the Oval Office, where he sported a black eye that he said came from his young son but that seemed to be a metaphor for his messy time in government service.', 'WATCH: Trump praises Musk for delivering ‘colossal change’ to Washington', 'Trump, who rarely misses an opportunity to zing his critics on appearance, brought it up Thursday.', '“I said, ‘Do you want a little makeup? We’ll get you a little makeup.’ Which is interesting,” Trump said.', 'The Republican president’s comments came as Musk has griped for days on social media about Trump’s spending bill, warning that it will increase the federal deficit. Musk has called the bill a “disgusting abomination.”', '“He hasn’t said bad about me personally, but I’m sure that will be next,” Trump said Thursday in the Oval Office, presaging the rest of his day. “But I’m very disappointed in Elon. I’ve helped Elon a lot.”', 'Observers had long wondered if the friendship between the two brash billionaires known for lobbing insults online would combust in dramatic fashion. It did, in less than a year.', 'White House aides were closely following the drama playing out on dueling platforms Thursday with bemusement, sharing the latest twists and turns from the feud between their boss and former co-worker, as well as the social media reaction and memes. Officials in the extremely online administration privately expressed the belief that like the other digital scuffles that have defined Trump’s political career, this would also work out in his favor.', 'Trump said Thursday in the Oval Office that he and Musk had had a great relationship but mused: “I don’t know if we will anymore.”', 'He said some people who leave his administration “miss it so badly” and “actually become hostile.”', '“It’s sort of Trump derangement syndrome, I guess they call it,” he said.', 'He brushed aside the billionaire’s efforts to get him elected last year, including a $1 million-a-day voter sweepstakes in Pennsylvania. The surge of cash Musk showed he was willing to spend seemed to set him up as a highly coveted ally for Republicans going forward, but his split with Trump, the party’s leader, raises questions about whether they or any others will see such a campaign windfall in the future.', 'Trump said Musk “only developed a problem” with the bill because it rolls back tax credits for electric vehicles.', '“False,” Musk fired back on his social media platform as the president continued speaking. “This bill was never shown to me even once and was passed in the dead of night so fast that almost no one in Congress could even read it!”', 'In another post, he said Trump could keep the spending cuts but “ditch the MOUNTAIN of DISGUSTING PORK in the bill.”', 'Besides Musk being “disturbed” by the electric vehicle tax credits, Trump said another point of contention was Musk’s promotion of Jared Isaacman to run NASA. Trump withdrew Isaacman’s nomination over the weekend and on Thursday called him “totally a Democrat.”', 'Musk continued slinging his responses on social media. He shared some posts Trump made over a decade ago criticizing Republicans for their spending, musings made when he, too, was just a billionaire lobbing his thoughts on social media.', '“Where is the man who wrote these words?” Musk wrote. “Was he replaced by a body double!?”', 'On the White House grounds Thursday afternoon, Trump’s red Tesla still sat in a parking lot.', 'Associated Press writers Chris Megerian, Zeke Miller and Eric Tucker in Washington and Bernard Condon and Paul Harloff in New York contributed to this report.', 'Your donation makes a difference in these uncertain times.', 'Left: President Donald Trump and Tesla CEO Elon Musk sit in a Tesla car model S, in front of the White House on March 11, 2025.
